title: Hario makes the best coffee dripper, but sometimes…
body:
The first thing to say is that I think Hario, who I believe actually invented the V60 coffee dripper, make an excellent product. I’ve read about and brewed coffee for years, since I was in my late teens, and I do believe that brewing filtered coffee from organically grown high-quality coffee beans is the best way of preparing this highly beneficial, healthy beverage rich in polyphenols.

The Hario dripper is made of CERAMIC - which again is an EXCELLENT choice. Plastic is basically a poison, both for planet Earth as well as almost all her animals and trees. Micro- and Nanoplastics now reside in almost every living animal and many trees, in the entire food chain, and are almost certainly deleterious to long term health. Specific families of plastics like BPA are proven carcinogens, and because regulation is so poor in most countries, thousands of these products are still used by ordinary people in daily life. It is not surprising that 1:2 humans will get cancer in their lifetime.

So I really do support HARIO making a ceramic dripper, and continuing to do so, despite the higher cost. On occasion it does break in transit, like my latest one did, but the price at which each is sold should off set the replacements needed.

title: The Only Pour Over Coffee Maker You Will Need
body:
As I write this review I am sipping on a delicious cup of java made with my beloved Hario pour over coffee maker.

I have used this ceramic device virtually every morning since 2019, when I originally purchased it. This means that this review is what I would consider "comprehensive" since the product has been tested for over 5 years, as of now!

The ceramic is of very high quality, it definitely stands the test of time. The inside has spiral grooves which helps the coffee flow down through the grounds. It also comes with a handy scoop for measuring your grounds.

The size of the maker might be smaller than you would expect, when compared to other pour over makers you may have seen. But do not worry this is not an issue, the size has no effect on the final product (coffee). I believe the size is actually optimal, not too big, not too small. It is the perfect size for a single cup of coffee.

After years of brewing coffee with this maker, I have created the ideal method for the perfect cup of Java!

First, take your coffee filter and place it in the maker. Pour hot/warm water on it so the entire filter is saturated/wetted with water. This helps mitigate the risk of any type of paper flavor passing into the final cup of coffee. After this, pour out the water from your mug and get ready to start brewing!

Put your measured scoop of coffee into the now wetted basket and pour just enough hot water over the grounds so everything is saturated with water. This allows the grounds to "bloom", which basically means release co2 so you have a more flavorful cup of coffee.

Let the grounds "bloom" for about 30 seconds then begin pouring hot water over the grounds until you have made a cup of coffee!

TL;DR This is the perfect single pour over coffee maker. I have used mine continually for over 5 years!

title: Good product, but maybe not as good as the plastic version.
body:
First off, the V60 brewing method is by far my favourite. You can keep your expensive machines, this simple method produces the best results with minimum hassle.
I've used the plastic version of this model for a few years now, I bought the plastic because it was cheap and if I didn't like the method I hadn't wasted much. It proved to be fantastic and I wondered if I shouldn't have bought the ceramic. The plastic beastie soldiered on though giving me great service until finally it snapped. No biggie, I'd definitely got my money's worth.
So to buy a new one. Splashed out on the 'upgrade' to ceramic.
First impressions, it feels nice and looks nice. Pleased.
Come to use though a couple of issues, albeit minor.
Firstly the fit. The papers just don't sit as well, the cone of the ceramic isn't quite the same profile as the plastic. It's smaller in height and internal, so the paper sits slightly proud of the top and doesn't settle in to the cone quite as well. It's not a big deal but it annoys me slightly.
Secondly the construction itself. Being ceramic it has more heat capacity, the advertisement sells this as a plus. Maybe it is, but you should bear in mind that that heat capacity will initially suck the heat out of your brew. I get around this by using more hot water to soak and flush the paper before adding grinds, thus getting the ceramic up to heat before brewing. Again, not a big deal but something I didn't have to worry about so much with the plastic.

Summary: a great product but not necessarily an upgrade over plastic thus not as good value.

title: とてもタイト
body:
多くの人は、安価なプラスチック製のものを使っているでしょう。私もそうでした。
プラと違って陶器製の最大の強みはその保温性能です。プラではすぐに冷めてしまいます。
陶器製は予めお湯に通しておくなどして温めておけば、淹れ終わって洗った後でも熱を保持しているほどです。

面白いのは、そのサイズ感。類似品があまりないのでペーパーは純正を使う事になります。
プラですと、セットしてリンスなり一投目なりで紙が「濡れた」時に、しっとりとくっついていきます。
温度で、プラのドリッパーも少し柔らかくなり、結果少し緩み・伸びるからではないかと思います。
一方陶器製だと、熱くなったり逆に冷たくなっても伸び縮みがほとんど起こりません。それ故に、ペーパーとの噛み合いがとてもタイトになります。密着度はプラ製以上です。

ドリッパーのマテリアルの差が、熱に対する反応の差、というのはとても面白い体験でした。

相応の重量（私のは305gでした）もあり、安定感は抜群です。
なお、ハリオの陶器ドリッパーは有田焼です。

ドリップスタンドに磁器製のV60を乗せて、マグカップを下において、ドリップいたしました。

そのため、磁器の方では、コーヒーの雫が広がって落ちてしまい、カップから外れてしまうことになります。
よって、このドリッパーをコーヒーサーバーの上に直接乗せてドリップしてみてください。

title: Guter Filterhalter, für kleine Mengen (Größe 01)
body:
Meine Anwendung:
Bin weder Kaffee-Gourmet, noch jemand, der die Zubereitung des Kaffees zelebriert. Für mich geht es nur darum, mir mit möglichst wenig Aufwand und ohne Kaffee-Maschine jeweils Kaffee für einen 350 ml Becher zuzubereiten.

Größe 01:
Die Größe 01 ist für diese Menge gerade so noch geeignet. Nachdem man den Filterhalter mit heißem Wasser gefüllt hat, muß man noch 2-3 mal Wasser nachgießen, bis ein 350 ml Becher gefüllt ist. Für mehrere Tassen, oder sogar Becher würde ich diese Größe nicht empfehlen. Der Filterhalter paßt auf Becher/Tassen von mindestens ca. 6,5 cm Innendurchmesser, bis maximal ca. 9,5 cm Außendurchmesser. Er steht sicher auf dem Becher, ohne zu wackeln.

Preis:
Der Preis von rund 16 EUR, den ich für den Filterhalter 01 bezahlt habe, finde ich noch in Ordnung, wesentlich mehr würde ich aber eher nicht dafür ausgeben.

Original Filter, oder herkömmliche Filter:
Ich hatte die Original-Filter für rund 6 EUR/60 Stück direkt dazu bestellt. Für jeden Becher Kaffee ergibt das 10 Cent, nur für den Filter. Das halte ich im Nachhinein für unnötig, da auch herkömmliche Filter verwendet werden können. Die müssen nur einmal gefaltet werden und passen dann gut in den Filterhalter. Ich verwende Profissimo Grösse 2. 120 Stück davon kosten 65 Cent und damit nur einen Bruchteil der Originalfilter. Ich bin, wie gesagt, kein Kaffee-Gourmet und schmecke keinen Unterschied bei der Verwendung dieser beiden verschiedenen Filtersorten.

Verarbeitung und Qualität:
Verarbeitung und Qualität des Halters sind gut. Die Glasur ist überall gleichmäßig vorhanden, bis auf die untere Kante, die etwas rau ist. Wenn man den Filterhalter auf extrem empfindlichen Oberflächen abstellt, muß man vielleicht etwas darauf achten. Für mich stellt das aber kein Problem dar.

Fazit:
Habe an dem Filterhalter nicht viel auszusetzen. Für meine übliche Menge von 350 ml Kaffee könnte er etwas größer sein. Andererseits gefällt mir aber auch die handliche Größe. Qualität und Verarbeitung sind einwandfrei. Auch läßt er sich sehr leicht von Hand reinigen. Der Preis geht mit 16 EUR in Ordnung. Ob man die sehr teuren Originalfilter verwenden will, muß jeder für sich entscheiden, für mich funktionieren herkömmliche Filter ebenso gut.

title: Great Cuppa, If I've Guessed Right How to Use It
body:
I've used a plastic one-cup Melitta for a year or so. Bought it while travelling, staying with non-coffee drinkers, and desperate for a good cup of coffee. When I returned home, I continued to use it 'cause I loved the simplicity of it.
But I really hate plastic.
When I read about the Hario dripper on the Real Simple website and found it came in a ceramic version, I immediately ordered it.
And yay! It arrived intact, pretty as the picture, with the filters I ordered. Only thing was, THE INSTRUCTIONS WERE ALL IN JAPANESE, and there were plenty of them! Well, OK, there was a picture of the thing with a few arrows. But I had to assume, with all those Japanese instructions, there had to be more to this thing than meets the eye.
Now, with the Melitta, I'd pour water in the middle to get the grounds wet, then fill up the filter, use a tablespoon to push the grounds down to the bottom, let it drain down, then fill it with water again. The coffee tasted fine to me. I just wanted something that wasn't plastic.
If the Hario promised to be any better, I decided on my own (after reading a bunch of reviews and intuiting from them how to use it) that I'd pour the water slowly and constantly down the middle and hope for the best. So that's what I do, and the cup of coffee I get is great. I think it's better than the one I get with the Melitta; it certainly takes more work.
But I'm subtracting a star for the deficit in instructions. I shouldn't have to guess how to use this device.

title: Very pleased with pourover coffee
body:
I purchased the Hario V60 01 ceramic pourover dripper along with the appropriate Hario filters, Buono kettle, and a Skerton (a Hario-splosion!) and am so pleased I could burst. I'm still working out the appropriate grind setting on the Skerton, but even so the coffee I've gotten from the pourover is just awesome. The quality is what you would expect: ceramic like a nice coffee mug. There are also ridges along the sides that keep the filter from plastering itself to the walls, preventing clogging since the coffee can run along the ridges instead of being forced to go all through the center bottom. The only problem I have is that I now want to spend more money to get the V60 02 and a carafe to make bigger batches of coffee!

Please be sure to get the right filters (i.e. specifically for pourover, and ideally the Hario brand) because, like in previous reviews, the filters are made to support the design of the dripper and the V60 is just one big hole on the bottom. If you use a filter that isn't designed to support the water and coffee, you'll probably experience ripped filters often. I suppose you might be able to double-up! May be worth doing the math to see if twice the number of Melitta or other filters cost less than the $12 for 100 Hario filters.

Also, it does take time to make pourover, so if you don't have 10 minutes to make coffee when you want it, it's probably not what you want.

brewmethods.com has some really good videos showing pourover (and other!) methods if you want to see it before you buy.

title: 5 stars minus 1 star for its recent inconsistency

Hence 5 stars for being an excellent product; minus 1 star for this new buy being not much of use for me.

title: personal office coffeemaker
body:
Hario is good quality ceramic dripper and from the package it is made in japan.

So far this is a good alternate way of making coffee in office. After trying many different ways of making a good cup of coffee in the office, I think I finally have found what I needed: Hario V60. This ceramic coffee maker fits in top of a normal sized coffee cup. Using Hario I don’t have to be concerned about plastic and other health issue in office coffeemakers(including Keurig). The setup is easy and takes about 3 minutes. The only issue is that by time I get my coffee ready, I find the coffee a little colder than I am used to. I am still working on refining my coffee making method. But one way I found that keep the coffee hotter is as follow:

I start by filling my coffee mug with hot water and I wait for about 20 seconds until the mug absorbs the heat from the water. I then pour out the water, place the coffee filter and starter pouring the water slowly (using the method described in the package). Once the coffee is done, I transfer to a thermos travel mug.

I also found that I can now drink coffee without a need for sugar! That is something I couldn’t do before with coffee from office coffeemakers.

Heat your water to a full boil then remove from the stove. The water will be around 200 degrees. Do one short pour and wait about 30 seconds.

Then pour the remaining water in a circular motion. Of course, there are videos online that get into great detail. It is all about consistency.

title: Love it with the Hario Kettle!
body:
I've stopped using my french press and my aero-press because I like the cleanup and taste. I use the Hario Buono Drip Kettle with the small spout to pour hot water over this dripper.

Setup:
1. Weigh the beans with a OXO Good Grips Stainless Food Scale with Pull-Out Display and grind with a Bodum Bistro Electric Burr Coffee Grinder, Black .
2. 21 grams of beans for 340 grams of water. Grind size is fine, but not like espresso.
3. Water temp 190-200F off the boil.
4. Water should be poured in the center (quarter size area)
5. The mug and and the hario v60 should be on the scale to measure the amount of water you add.

Brew Recipe
1. Boil water and pour into hario kettle.
2. Wet the filter and heat up the cup for ~10 seconds. (dump water in sink)
3. Pour 40 grams of water to pre-wet the grinds.
4. Stir and wait ~30 seconds
5. Pour 300 grams and final stir. (~2:00 - 2:30 minutes:seconds)

Add hot milk or hot water to dilute to your preferred strength.

title: Beautiful piece on the shelf, frustrating to use
body: I bought the Hario coffee dripper to replace the plastic dripper I've been using for years. I was so excited to discover this item, I had no idea a ceramic version existed! When it arrived, I was very surprised at the large, almost nickel (5 cents) size drip hole. I'm used to seeing 3 small holes, allowing the coffee to drip efficiently. I used the Hario dripper for several weeks. It worked ~70% of the time. It didn't work for the following reason: the drip hole is too big. So, when water is poured into the dripper, the weight of the water and coffee would result in a catastrophic collapse, the filter would rip/break and coffee and water contents would flush into the cup. I use fairly expensive organic coffee and this would irritate me to no end, as I'd have to throw out the contents and begin the process over. And, then, I'd be nervous that it would happen again. Yes, some may argue that one must prime the filter by slowly pouring the water over the filter and coffee. I did this, I also hovered over the process slowly dripping hot boiling water (hoping the water stayed hot) over the coffee and even then, I'd occasionally experience the catastrophic collapse. And, really, the coffee wasn't any better than coffee I've made using a plastic dripper, I dare suggest it was even worse because it was cooler, much cooler because the process took so darn long. I didn't want to hover over the coffee, how annoying, resulting in several cranky mornings. I'm annoyed by this entire product! While it is a lovely piece of ceramic engineering, much like a toilet, but at least a toilet works.

title: 湯を注ぐ速度の訓練必要
body:

セットで「HARIO(ハリオ) V60コーヒーサーバー 電子レンジ/食洗機対応 450ml ブラック 日本製 VCS-01B」、「HARIO(ハリオ) V60ドリップケトル・ヴォーノ ガス火・IH対応 実用600ml シルバー 日本製 VKB-100HSV」、「HARIO (ハリオ) V60 用 ペーパーフィルター 01W 1~2杯用 100枚入り ホワイト VCF-01-100W」を同時に購入しました。

今までドリッパーは台形型（三つ穴）のものを使用していましたが、円すい型で挑戦したいと思い、こちらを購入しました。
円すい型は、湯量の調整がむずかしく、最初は一気に流れてしまってコーヒーの味が薄くなってしましましたが、
同時に購入した「HARIO(ハリオ) V60ドリップケトルVKB-100HSV」でドリップの注ぐ湯量の調節して細くしたり、一気に注いだりして、練習をしています。毎回異なる出来に「昨日は70点、今日は75点」など自己評価しています。
他に、プラスチックやガラス、金属のものもありますが、セラミックは重いですが、有田焼で高級感があり、所有欲を満たしてくれます。見た目も素晴らしいです。
ドリップする前に、フィルターをセットして湯通しをして、ドリッパーを温めてから、注ぐようにしています。
コーヒーをいれるのが楽しいです。

title: The Classic Pour-Over Mechanism
body:
I work in a cafe in Chicago, and my wife manages a couple more. Both of us have worked in cafes off and on for the last ten years. The V60 has become an essential facet of the modern coffee shop for good reason-- it makes an incredible cup of coffee easily. It's also pretty cheap, but you pay a bit of a premium for filters.

We use 24g coarse-ground coffee/ 350g water for a 12-ounce cup, and do a 50-gram (roughly) "bloom" pour at the beginning, then wait 30 seconds and pour the rest. Different shops use different ratios or have ratios that are specific to different blends, but that's the idea. Pour slowly and move the kettle counterclockwise, avoiding the sides so water doesn't just run down the mechanism.

title: Perfect. I never knew this cup existed.
body: I've only had it a few days, but it's been perfect. Fits right over a normal size mug. Doesn't stain. I only make one cup, so a carafe would have been too big. I like it alot.
author: LF
date: Revisado en los Estados Unidos el 8 de marzo de 2019

title: Excellent quality dripper
body: I brought the plastic Hario V60 dripper back from Japan and used it for about 1.5 years before the plastic began to develop cracks, so I replaced it with the ceramic version. I'm very pleased by the quality of this ceramic dripper, and I suppose its only downside is that you can't see how full your cup as become when you're pouring over your coffee. But overall, this is an excellent coffee dripper for a pour-over.
